The game isn't all too different from the past generations. Though the thing that makes me recommend this game, is the free starter pack. 

If you're like me, and own older TSW games, the starter pack is great! You get the new game, just without any of the new trains (that's why it's free) but the good thing is, all your older routes transfer over! 

For some of you who don't already own TSW content, you can simply purchase the game which is often on sale. And when TSW 7 eventually comes out next year, the content you got when purchasing TSW6 will transfer over. 

If you haven't ever tried a TSW game, and don't want to purchase the game until you know you'll like it, the free starter pack comes with a small map that is almost like a training facility/sandbox. It has a few trains that you can play around with and test out, to see if you'll like the game or not.

I'm personally not a fan of the devs practically re-releasing the same game every year, just with a handful of new routes. But as long as they keep the free starter pack as an option, I'd say the game franchise as a whole is decent.

[b] Lets start with the good: [/b]
This overall is a very fun train simulator/game.
Balances realism and playability well most of the time.

You can play with or without safety systems most of the time which makes the game/simulator more accessible.

Works well under the default Proton on Linux (Arch in my case) which is a nice bonus.

Quality can be hit or miss depending on the DLC(s) you get.
As of writing this the only good European route not located in Germany for me is Zwolle - Groningen which is well made and works well overall.

Most DLC have a good amount of services and things to do. There often are multiple types of services such as passenger runs, cargo runs and even shunting operations.
There also is the conductor mode which seemed like, and can be a fun addition. I tried it a few times and was rather disappointed with it; more on this below.


[b] On to the not quite so good: [/b]
Unfortunately the French LGV route is rather poor in quality and detail, especially environmental detail is lacking. It only includes one train type, the TGV Duplex 200 CM. This makes the route feel rather bland and empty at times. The safety systems are rather lackluster in terms of implementation (I am aware this is an older route from TSW2 but I still think this can be important to note as it is still on sale for TSW6 and some of its issues such as the buggy/wrong implementation of TVM and safety systems should be addressed)

Unfortunately being made with Unreal Engine doesn't help this game as it has the dreaded stutters when loading in new areas while driving basically all the time.

The conductor mode is rather basic and quite buggy at times (think being unable to check tickets from certain passengers, a service not properly detecting you close the doors etc.) A lot of the issues with this also stem from the relatively bad passenger system, which should have been addressed before adding the conductor mode.
The conductor mode to me is more of a novelty and I personally would not care if it was never added or were to be removed entirely.

There is a distinct lack of custom controller support, which has been a community (and personal) request for quite a while. There now is the HTTP API, but it is rather hard to use as it is basically undocumented from what I could find.


[b] Overall: [/b]
Overall this game/simulator has a lot of potential to be really good, but it desperately needs more optimization, lots more bug fixing and a proper direction to go towards instead of trying to be everything at once.

[b] I still recommend this as it currently is, for the average person it will still be a very enjoyable game/simulator as long as you stick to the better made/rated DLCs [/b]

Train Sim World 6 is Dovetail Games’ latest entry in its long-running railway simulation series, a franchise that has steadily evolved into one of the most immersive and detailed train-driving experiences available. Developed and published by Dovetail Games under the TSW label, this installment continues the studio’s commitment to authenticity, expanding on the systems and realism that have defined the series. Rather than reinventing the formula, it builds upon the foundation established in previous entries, refining features, introducing new mechanics like random train faults and station announcements, and delivering a fresh set of routes that take players across some of the world’s most iconic rail networks. For those who find joy in the rhythmic hum of steel wheels on track and the delicate balance between precision and timing, Train Sim World 6 offers a familiar yet deeper dive into the art and discipline of railroading.

At its core, Train Sim World 6 remains focused on recreating the genuine experience of operating real trains, from suburban commuter services to high-speed passenger runs and industrial freight operations. Each locomotive is rendered with meticulous attention to detail, complete with fully interactive cabs, authentic controls, and accurately simulated safety and power systems. The developers have painstakingly modeled real-world systems such as PZB and LZB in Germany, AWS and TPWS in the United Kingdom, and ACSES in the United States, ensuring that every button, lever, and indicator serves a purpose. The new Train Faults system introduces an additional layer of unpredictability, allowing various equipment failures such as lighting issues or turbo malfunctions to occur mid-route, demanding on-the-fly troubleshooting. This feature pushes the simulation closer to the unpredictability of real-life train operations, rewarding players who have taken the time to understand every aspect of their vehicle’s inner workings.

The game’s content selection is as strong as ever, shipping with three distinct routes that span multiple countries and operational styles. Players can navigate the busy NJ Transit Morristown Line in the United States, balancing tight commuter schedules through the metropolitan sprawl of New York and New Jersey. Across the Atlantic, the Riviera Line in the United Kingdom offers a scenic journey along the Devon coast, combining the relaxed beauty of rural England with the challenge of maintaining precision along winding tracks. Meanwhile, the Leipzig–Dresden route in Germany delivers high-speed ICE services and freight operations through one of Europe’s most dynamic rail corridors. Each route comes with its own locomotives, services, and challenges, offering a diverse mix of gameplay that keeps the experience fresh. The improved layering system ensures that trains from previous DLCs can integrate seamlessly into the new routes, creating a dynamic network where the player’s collection of locomotives feels increasingly interconnected.

Visually, Train Sim World 6 achieves a level of polish that continues to set the series apart. The environments are richly detailed, with realistic lighting effects, varied weather patterns, and time-of-day changes that transform familiar routes into completely different experiences depending on the conditions. The interiors of train cabs are beautifully crafted, down to the texture of worn levers and the subtle reflections on glass panels. The passenger ambience has also seen noticeable improvement, with station announcements, crowd chatter, and realistic movement lending more life to the world. There is a genuine sense of place that the visuals and sound design together achieve—whether you are crawling through a foggy morning in rural Germany or racing through a thunderstorm toward New York Penn Station. Despite its strengths, however, performance can be inconsistent at times, with pop-in textures and framerate dips occasionally breaking immersion, particularly on older hardware.

From a gameplay perspective, Train Sim World 6 walks a careful line between accessibility and authenticity. For newcomers, the game’s tutorials are a welcome starting point, guiding players through the complexities of train operation step by step. Yet beneath that surface lies a depth that will satisfy even the most dedicated rail enthusiasts. Learning to read the signals, managing speed limits, controlling braking systems, and dealing with random mechanical faults all require patience and concentration. The addition of a more dynamic passenger system and live station announcements gives context to your performance—miss a stop or mishandle a departure, and the world responds accordingly. Time management remains critical, as each route challenges players to balance efficiency with safety, and the tension of racing against the clock without sacrificing precision creates moments of genuine excitement. This installment doesn’t aim to be a casual game; it’s a meticulous recreation of railway operations that rewards persistence and attention to detail.

Criticism of Train Sim World 6 largely stems from its evolutionary rather than revolutionary design. For long-time fans, the new features—while appreciated—may not feel like a substantial leap forward from the previous version. Much of the interface, physics, and presentation remain consistent with earlier titles, and some players view this installment as a refinement rather than a bold step. The learning curve remains steep, and the short selection of base routes means that the true value of the game is unlocked only when paired with additional DLCs. Nevertheless, Dovetail’s long-term strategy of building an expanding, modular ecosystem continues to pay off for those invested in the series. Each release builds upon the player’s existing collection, integrating older trains and routes into new environments, creating a sense of continuity and investment that few simulation franchises can match.

What ultimately makes Train Sim World 6 stand out is its commitment to immersion and authenticity. Every journey feels deliberate, every control meaningful, and every successful arrival satisfying. The addition of minor systems such as random faults and environmental effects brings an organic unpredictability to an experience that could otherwise feel mechanical. There is a meditative quality to its gameplay—an almost therapeutic rhythm in following procedures, monitoring signals, and hearing the steady hum of the tracks beneath your wheels. It’s a game that asks for patience and precision but rewards both with moments of quiet triumph. While not a complete reinvention, it represents a steady evolution in the franchise’s pursuit of realism.

In the end, Train Sim World 6 is less about novelty and more about refinement. It doesn’t radically alter the series’ formula, but it deepens and enriches what already works. For railway enthusiasts, it’s another step toward the definitive train simulation experience—complex, immersive, and endlessly replayable. For newcomers, it remains one of the best entry points into the world of modern rail simulations, offering intuitive tutorials, stunning environments, and a tangible sense of authenticity. Despite some technical blemishes and the familiar Dovetail pricing model, Train Sim World 6 continues to uphold the series’ reputation as the gold standard for digital train operations—a world where every journey tells its own story, one mile of track at a time.

Train Sim World 6 continues the established predatory formula of Dovetail Games’ railway simulation series. I entered the franchise with Train Sim World 4, and even I have a difficult time discerning significant advancements in this iteration compared to its predecessors, including TSW5. While TSW offers a respectable simulation experience with visually adequate graphics and a diverse roster of both historic and contemporary locomotives, the core gameplay remains largely unchanged.

The annual release cycle is the primary problem. The game feels less like a substantial sequel and more like a repackaging of existing content supplemented by new, full-price routes. This approach has no longevity, as the game is designed to be superseded by the next "platform" 12 months later. The new DLC will not be compatible with previous releases forcing players to either get the 'Free Starter Pack' or pay in full for the new 'release'.

Furthermore, there are persistent bugs present in earlier versions that CONTINUE to plague the experience. I am particularly frustrated about the availability of a specific DLC (the Japanese line) in the works, which is the reason why I purchased TSW4, and is more than likely going to be pushed to whatever latest TSW entry there is. After writing this review, I'll give up on waiting for that one DLC and will push on to other games.

[h1] This is such a mixed bag [/h1]
[i] I've only played German routes so far so my review will focus on that aspect. [/i]
It's pretty clear that this is a game first, simulator second. Almost every time you start a scenario, you're put into the drivers' seat with the locomotive already fully started and all safety systems turned off by default. There is no option in the settings menu to have all the safety features like PZB/LZB and SiFa turned on by default, and no true expert mode where you have to fully start up the train yourself. There is a so-called expert mode but it doesn't keep these systems turned on by default, which in real life would be illegal to cut out and grounds for getting fired.

[h2] Then there are the bugs. [/h2]
[list]
[*] On multiple occasion you literally run into issues such as PZB magnets being placed incorrectly, or the 500Hz speed limit display not being accurate, forcing the train into an emergency brake sequence when you've actually been operating it correctly.
[*] Signal aspects on German routes not being accurate and sometimes displaying entirely non-existent aspects that would make the signal to be considered faulty, especially in shunting order scenarios where substitute signalling (Zs) would be required to shunt past a Hp0 signal
[*] Doors that can in reality only be opened from the outside but not closed again being able to be closed again (this occurs with several pieces of rolling stock across several DLC)
[*] Many German routes don't implement the [H] sign so you never know where to stop without the overlay
[*] Speed limit signage stating one speed limit while the game enforces another
[*] PZB not activating speed limit indicators on the speedometer, requiring you to enable the overlay for the HUD
[*] Rolling stock from different DLC not correctly detecting that coupling has occurred, leaving gangway plates raised and roller shutters closed, with some coaches not even having manual controls, so there is no way of making a mixed consist - it appears that there is no unified API for this so different rolling stock can't fully interact beyond basic the basic coupling process
[*] Graphics can vary by route drastically - Each DLC route appears to have its own colour grading, meaning some routes may have a weird blue-green-ish tinge, others a weirdly orange colour bias, etc. You would basically have to use several different ReShade presets for each route to fix this. Some DLCs are worse than others with this
[*] Blurry graphics at a distance - I can't say whether this is due to my very modest custom quality settings, but this is an ongoing issue for me. Objects and world geometry that is far away appears so blurry that it feels almost like I need new glasses...
[*] The sound often glitches out with weird artifacts, like random buzzing
[/list]

[h2] Missing features: [/h2]
[list]
[*] a working EBULA on basically every locomotive and MU that supports it. The monitor is always empty and there is no way to operate with realistic helper options such as this, over the HUD.
Imagine the game had a built-in server with an official app that allowed your phone or tablet to connect to it and display the EBULA, or a client on the PC you're playing on can display it on a second monitor! While you're at it, you could allow for gauges and such to be displayed as well.
There's a certain simulator that has this features. Rhymes with INDUSI and starts with a Z.
[*] There's no way to use rolling stock that didn't come with a specific map in a regular schedule on that specific map. Only prescribed rolling stock for you, or free roam!
[*] an open interface for custom control desks - only the RailDriver is fully supported
[*] You can't always interact with every button and window. Ie the cab windows on the ICE 3 can't be opened
[*] There is no way of leaning out of cab windows to monitor the boarding process like you would as a driver normally
[*] A lot of rolling stock doesn't natively allow you to walk through the engine compartment to change ends (BR 110 & BR 103) - you need to download mods to achieve this which may or may not stop working after updates
[/list]


[h2] The positives: [/h2]
[list]
[*] The atmosphere! Oh the atmosphere! Sometimes the graphics up close just nails it. Things like driving at night in the snow, or in the evening while drenched in the pink shades of dusk can be absolutely wonderful!
[*] Realistic-feeling camera wobble - While at speed, the camera simulates an amount of train hunting and wobbling that just feels right. Not too understated, not too exaggerated. It very much adds to the feeling of being on a train at speed, even though you yourself aren't actually experiencing that physical movement like on a proper training simulator
[*] Level of detail - I'm a 3D modeller myself and I'm really impressed with the level of detail of both the models and most textures of the trains at least. 
[/list]

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]
Don't buy this if you're a really die-hard, sweaty engine driver who requires absolute realism with fully working PZB and LZB.
If you're not the former, only buy this and DLC at a discount. It's fun to play as a quick way of hopping onto a train and driving a service for the vibes, but don't expect perfection or a bug-free experience. I'd say this is only one step above an arcade experience.

If DTG put more emphasis on a bug-free experience with perfect simulation quality in mind, as well as open interfaces that allow for custom control desks, EBULA support on a second monitor or on mobile devices, fully accurate signalling and more attention to operational minutia of rolling stock and locomotives, this could be the best simulator there is. But right now, it's only a sort of casual sim game that can't be taken too seriously.
I really want this to be great, but right now it's only "sort of barely good enough". If it took the simulation aspect more seriously, gave you the option for different difficulty settings for the grading at the end (right now it's far too forgiving of things like SiFa and PZB/LZB forced brake applications, rough driving style on passenger services and much more not being taken into account at all), and allowed you to turn off things like the stop markers and achievement notifications (the latter always blocking the horizon when they pop up so you might end up missing signals and signage) alongside other gamification features, this could easily be the best simulator there is. But right now, it just isn't. 
A lot of wasted potential here. I hope they get it right eventually.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
I have a total of 20 hours in Train Sim World, and 1.5k hours in Train Sim Classic. I bought into this ecosystem when it was called Railworks 2, 15 years ago at the time of writing. The only way I can describe the business model of these games is predatory and user unfriendly (anti consumer even). [b]Bugs don't get fixed[/b], they re-release the game as if it was new each year, which makes you re-download tens of gigabytes of your game and all your DLC. The pricing is horrible, and the quality control is non existent. These practices have been observed consistently throughout my 15 year interest in these games, with no sign of changing. [b]Avoid.[/b]

[h2] Big No's from me [/h2]
[list]
[*]Developer has gone back on their word. Features promised at the start of development have evaporated. Multiplayer was dangled on a stick for so long in the first few versions.
[*]This game is re released each year with minimal to no bug fixes for previous content. There are speculations as to why they do this, like to "game the store algorithm" and to reset all reviews of the product. They used to make you re-purchase it each year which is foul, as it was fundamentally the same game but with minor extra features added. At least they don't make you buy it each year anymore (if you catch the limited time window) but you still have to re-download the game. In Train Sim Classic (and almost any other software) these features would simply be released as additions to the existing software. Imagine if Minecraft made you re-purchase the game to add Camels, and then you'd have to buy it again for the Trial Chambers the next year too.
[*]Little quality control on any releases, new or old. Bugs exist that are 8 years old at this point. No guarantee that they will patch any content into the future. If something releases with issues then it will most likely remain with these issues.
[*]Hideous amount of DLC - downloadable content you can buy separately. Yes, it allows users to choose specifically what types of trains and locations they download individually instead of making the game overwhelmingly massive by default. But the pricing is eye-gouging, especially with the quality control and the forced re-download every year.
[*]Did I mention that you have to download everything again each year if you want to update to that year's version? Even though the changes could be applied as a patch, the same with the DLC, but instead you have to download the whole game and each DLC you own AGAIN. Not only is that terrible for your storage drive's life span, but it is horrible for people with slow internet speeds. Oh and this also will reset your hour count if that's something you like to track. I had to add up my separate TSW version hour counts thanks to this. It's just weird that I have to do that.
[*]Tutorials are useless at best and broken at worst. The trains are complicated to use and the official tutorials are lacklustre at helping new players understand how to operate these machines above a standard of making the train move if it's already correctly set up. That's if the tutorial isn't broken in a way that makes it impossible to complete or restrictive in very weird ways.
[/list]

[h2] Weirder stuff I also don't like [/h2]
[list]
[*]Graphics aren't bad, but they're certainly not good. Everything has a shiny plastic feel to it, while also having washed out colours to create a very dull vibe. The engine used is also outdated now, but I do at least respect that it would take a lot of development time to port to the updated Unreal 5 engine.
[*]Audio is unreasonably quiet compared to other applications. 
[*]Train sounds vary in quality. Some sound synthetic and fake, others sound like the real thing. It's a real gamble. This alone is a deal breaker for me, but this very much my weird personal preference.
[*]Routes can be unimpressive in immersion with little detailing.
[*]AI has officially been confirmed to be used in this game. There are signs that they have used it in some marketing materials too.
[*]Getting really opinionated here, but I hate the language surrounding their use of proprietary tools to market the software as something professionally made and bespoke in its design, when in actual fact it's known that the previous Train Simulator Classic has been used in professional settings to train actual railway staff before, the same cannot be said about this. But I also hate this on the grounds that SimuGraph - the software they developed in-house that simulates the trains physics - sounds and looks very impressive, but is completely closed source and only usable in this game by themselves or other developers they license development to. I think the game and the community would be in a much healthier state if SimuGraph was open source even under a limiting license, but I understand that it's just their choice to be proprietary and closed off the source, as is there right. That and if they fixed the re-release bullshit.
[/list]

[h3] Edit [/h3]
[list]
[*]Formatting
[*]Added sections on tutorials and SimuGraph
[/list]

[h1]TL;DR - Dovetail Games does not care for your enjoyment of the game, their only care is harvesting as much money from you with as little effort as possible.[/h1]

[hr][/hr]

"[...] and this year we have prioritised requests directly from you, our lovely community, [i]you asked we deliver.[/i]" ~Dovetail Games during Dovetail Direct 2025.

Unless everyone wanted another re-release of the exact same game riddled with bugs, no one asked for this, nor did they for Train Sim World 5, 4 or even 3. With Dovetail's track record, I have almost no doubt that even though they 'listen' to their community, this game is just another cash grab destined to become abandonware next year.

Now I will say that I enjoy playing this game, but the mindset of the team at Dovetail is just abhorrent and should never be supported. So what's wrong...

[h2]Bugs, bugs and more bugs[/h2]

24 hours before the release of the game, Dovetail did a stream showcasing the Riviera Line revealing loads of glitches and bugs at such a late stage before pre-release. It really showed how little Dovetail cares about quality and would prefer to pump out as much content as possible to earn the most money. These bugs progressed into pre-release including game breaking bugs and even incorrect versions of the game being released to some consoles making it almost unplayable. Some of these bugs have still not yet been patched out since attention is probably being spent in releasing the next bug ridden £29.99 DLC.

I'm almost certain that very little money is put into Quality Assurance. There is no way that with the amount of issues that are present in every route, they are just simply missed.

What makes it worse is while Dovetail patch out some of the major bugs (after release, effectively making the user a paying playtester), minor ones remain in the game and are never looked at again. Bugs that have existed as part of routes from TSW 2020 (the original game) still exist 5 years later in this iteration. Instead they just move onto the next route because optimisation doesn't bring in the money.

[h2]Engine and Performance[/h2]

This game is the same as before, the same engine, and the same graphics as TSW 2020, TSW 2, 3, 4 and 5. TSW runs on the outdated Unreal Engine 4 so there's a limitation in graphics quality. While modelling of trains is typically well done, the overall graphics are substandard. I can understand why the company would be averted to updating the game engine to UE5, but it would bring about a much needed change to the game's dated graphical quality. Instead, they will continue to run on the outdated (and eventually obsolete) UE4. In my case, I need to install [b]over 100 mods[/b] to overhaul the graphics and enhance the routes that I play to an acceptable standard.

Performance is poor as well. Without mods my frame rate jumps frequently: maybe 80 FPS in the countryside but then as low as 20 in main stations. While performance has improved over iterations, it definitely isn't up to par. For reference, I get a higher average FPS playing games like Cyberpunk 2077 and Red Dead Redemption 2 (between 60-100 fps) with raytracing enabled (a function that this game still doesn't have - which could be related to the outdated engine as well).

Additionally while playing, textures constantly pop into view, completely ruining the immersion that is essential for a simulator. Seeing grass, trees, track, overhead wires, etc, pop into existence is not acceptable and has been present throughout all iterations of TSW.

If you want to know how much Dovetail loves your money, you need look no further than their console support. They [i]still[/i] support gen 8 consoles (eg: PS4 and Xbox One). It's hardly even playable on there forcing a reduced timetable to be made for routes, which makes them feel deserted. Even with this, they still have the audacity to charge full price for it.

[h2]Annual Re-Releases of the Same Game[/h2]

[h3]But the free starter pack...[/h3]
I am aware of the starter pack; it is the reason that I can write this review. It is much better than when you had to pay for the game again to carry over your DLCs. But it doesn't take away that every year every user needs to re-download [b]HUNDREDS[/b] of gigabytes of content, which in some cases can take days. If it was an engine update I would understand why a whole new version is necessary but this isn't the case, its the same engine and graphics just with a slightly different colour pallete applied to the UI and with small features which could be easily be patched into the existing game.

[h3]Why do Dovetail have this model?[/h3]
Well, it obviously brings in more cash to the company but there are more convenient and shadier reasons for this model:

1. Releasing products marketed as "new" improves visibility on Steam (and I assume other platforms).
2. Re-releasing the game and its DLC under resets [b]all[/b] reviews for the product on Steam.

The second one is particularly troubling. This wipes all of people's opinions making it harder for buyers to easily find accounts of user experience and product quality. This makes the base game and previously released DLC look more favourable to consumers. Valid negative (and also positive) reviews are wiped every year by Dovetail, which could have been critical in determining a buyer's purchase decision. While this is obviously speculation, Dovetail's DLCs are known to the community to be questionable in quality in some cases so given their track record and business model, I wouldn't be surprised if this is actually one of the reasons for the annual releases.

[h2]Can Dovetail Redeem themselves?[/h2]

While my opinion will probably be overlooked or ignored by Dovetail, I have a slither of hope that this company can change. Right now it feels like they couldn't care less about their consumers or their trust. So what can Dovetail do? Here are some ideas:

- Stop re-releasing the same game every year. For the next 'major' update to the game, re-brand the page and game title to "Train Sim World." From there, all updates should be pushed to the same version until the game's end of life.
- I never blame the devs for these shortcomings as it is more likely the fault of the executives. So for them, you need to have more respect for your customers. Listen to their feedback and act on it, otherwise you will lose more customers every year you follow this model. A good place to start would be Steam reviews, Steam discussions and comments on your Steam news articles as a lot of frustration is present there. Use them to your advantage to understand what consumers want and don't want with your products.
- Look at previous DLCs and games and patch out some of the older bugs plaguing this game instead of sweeping them under the rug. Bugs and glitches are present in every game made, but that doesn't make a game bad. What does is when companies don't listen to bug reports and concerns from players; instead focusing their attention on the thing that can bring in money for the cheapest rate. By improving quality and support across the board of DLCs you build a stronger rapport with your consumers, giving players trust in the quality of future content.

[h2]Summary[/h2]

This company has such an annoying and questionable business model releasing the same game again and again. These releases just show that there is no more love in this game, it's just all about the money.

I do have a slither of hope left for Dovetail, if they actively work with their customers, they can make this game a lot more than what it is now. I will continue playing this game and keep up to date on what Dovetail are up to. I will update this review if changes are made to improve their attitude however for now [b][i]I cannot recommend anyone to purchase any product from Dovetail.[/i][/b]

The Riviera route is a real standout in terms of the quality of the scenery and general attention-to-detail. It is also one of the prettiest routes in TSW, as it is in the UK in real life. I have spent a fair bit of time on this route, including walking the length from Exeter Central to Teignmouth and the route brought back some memories. Overall stance here is that TSW6 is worth it for the new route, but that I can't really recommend it. If you want a good route, I instead recommend some of the better routes from previous installments, like Niddertalbahn or Peak Forest Railway, and the free upgrade to 6 if you really want the "new" UI. There is a so-called expert mode but it doesn't keep these systems turned on by default, which in real life would be illegal to cut out and grounds for getting fired.

[h2] Then there are the bugs. [/h2]
[list]
[*] On multiple occasion you literally run into issues such as PZB magnets being placed incorrectly, or the 500Hz speed limit display not being accurate, forcing the train into an emergency brake sequence when you've actually been operating it correctly.
[*] Signal aspects on German routes not being accurate and sometimes displaying entirely non-existent aspects that would make the signal to be considered faulty, especially in shunting order scenarios where substitute signalling (Zs) would be required to shunt past a Hp0 signal
[*] Doors that can in reality only be opened from the outside but not closed again being able to be closed again (this occurs with several pieces of rolling stock across several DLC)
[*] Many German routes don't implement the [H] sign so you never know where to stop without the overlay
[*] Speed limit signage stating one speed limit while the game enforces another
[*] PZB not activating speed limit indicators on the speedometer, requiring you to enable the overlay for the HUD
[*] Rolling stock from different DLC not correctly detecting that coupling has occurred, leaving gangway plates raised and roller shutters closed, with some coaches not even having manual controls, so there is no way of making a mixed consist - it appears that there is no unified API for this so different rolling stock can't fully interact beyond basic the basic coupling process
[*] Graphics can vary by route drastically - Each DLC route appears to have its own colour grading, meaning some routes may have a weird blue-green-ish tinge, others a weirdly orange colour bias, etc. You would basically have to use several different ReShade presets for each route to fix this. Some DLCs are worse than others with this
[*] Blurry graphics at a distance - I can't say whether this is due to my very modest custom quality settings, but this is an ongoing issue for me. Objects and world geometry that is far away appears so blurry that it feels almost like I need new glasses...
[*] The sound often glitches out with weird artifacts, like random buzzing
[/list]

[h2] Missing features: [/h2]
[list]
[*] a working EBULA on basically every locomotive and MU that supports it. The monitor is always empty and there is no way to operate with realistic helper options such as this, over the HUD.
Imagine the game had a built-in server with an official app that allowed your phone or tablet to connect to it and display the EBULA, or a client on the PC you're playing on can display it on a second monitor! While you're at it, you could allow for gauges and such to be displayed as well.
There's a certain simulator that has this features. Rhymes with INDUSI and starts with a Z.
[*] There's no way to use rolling stock that didn't come with a specific map in a regular schedule on that specific map. Only prescribed rolling stock for you, or free roam!
[*] an open interface for custom control desks - only the RailDriver is fully supported
[*] You can't always interact with every button and window. Ie the cab windows on the ICE 3 can't be opened
[*] There is no way of leaning out of cab windows to monitor the boarding process like you would as a driver normally
[*] A lot of rolling stock doesn't natively allow you to walk through the engine compartment to change ends (BR 110 & BR 103) - you need to download mods to achieve this which may or may not stop working after updates
[/list]


[h2] The positives: [/h2]
[list]
[*] The atmosphere! Oh the atmosphere! Sometimes the graphics up close just nails it. Things like driving at night in the snow, or in the evening while drenched in the pink shades of dusk can be absolutely wonderful!
[*] Realistic-feeling camera wobble - While at speed, the camera simulates an amount of train hunting and wobbling that just feels right. Not too understated, not too exaggerated. It very much adds to the feeling of being on a train at speed, even though you yourself aren't actually experiencing that physical movement like on a proper training simulator
[*] Level of detail - I'm a 3D modeller myself and I'm really impressed with the level of detail of both the models and most textures of the trains at least. 
[/list]

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]
Don't buy this if you're a really die-hard, sweaty engine driver who requires absolute realism with fully working PZB and LZB.
If you're not the former, only buy this and DLC at a discount. It's fun to play as a quick way of hopping onto a train and driving a service for the vibes, but don't expect perfection or a bug-free experience. I'd say this is only one step above an arcade experience.

If DTG put more emphasis on a bug-free experience with perfect simulation quality in mind, as well as open interfaces that allow for custom control desks, EBULA support on a second monitor or on mobile devices, fully accurate signalling and more attention to operational minutia of rolling stock and locomotives, this could be the best simulator there is. But right now, it's only a sort of casual sim game that can't be taken too seriously.
I really want this to be great, but right now it's only "sort of barely good enough". If it took the simulation aspect more seriously, gave you the option for different difficulty settings for the grading at the end (right now it's far too forgiving of things like SiFa and PZB/LZB forced brake applications, rough driving style on passenger services and much more not being taken into account at all), and allowed you to turn off things like the stop markers and achievement notifications (the latter always blocking the horizon when they pop up so you might end up missing signals and signage) alongside other gamification features, this could easily be the best simulator there is. But right now, it just isn't. 
A lot of wasted potential here. I hope they get it right eventually.
